Graphical abstract Palladium nanoparticles supported on carbon black were synthesized by two different methods precipitation- reduction (PR) and urea-assisted sodium formate homogeneous deposition (HD). The catalysts were then submitted to thermal treatments at 573K, 873K and 1173K to produce catalysts with a wide range of particle sizes. The obtained catalysts were characterized by XPS, TEM CO chemisorption and TGA measurements and tested in the oxidative dehydrogenation of glucose to gluconic acid. It was found that catalysts with a palladium particles size of 7nm exhibit the highest activity. Above or below this particular value the oxidative dehydrogenation of glucose appeared less efficient. Keywords Glucose Dehydrogenation Oxidation Palladium Catalyst Nanoparticles Carbon black 1 Introduction Since many years the development of sustainable alternatives to non-renewable fossil feedstock has attracted researchers across the world [1]. In this context, carbohydrates, derived from lignocellulosic biomass represent an attractive option for the production of high added-value compounds with pharmaceutical and fine chemistry applications [2–4]. Due to the difficulty in controlling selectivity of carbohydrate transformations, most industrial processes are based on chemo-catalytic methodologies that involve enzyme and microbial biocatalysts [5,6]. However, the use of biocatalysts has limitations such as stability, high cost and difficulty in recovery after catalytic reaction. The replacement of enzymatic process by supported catalysts is an interesting alternative to overcome these drawbacks [7]. Sugar conversion using heterogeneous catalysts has been the subject of many investigations, such as those mentioned in a recent review [8]. In general, carbohydrate transformation is carried out in aqueous liquid phase and produces various chemical intermediates by numerous biomass-based reactions such as hydrolysis, hydrogenation, oxidation, dehydration, isomerization, aldol condensation and reforming [1]. Glucose, a saccharide derived from cellulose hydrolysis, is a platform chemical to synthesize valuable products. It can be converted into ethanol (fermentation), sorbitol (hydrogenation), 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (dehydration), hydrogen (reforming), gluconic acid (oxidation) and by combining several types of reactions it is possible to produce a wide range of products [8] (Fig. 1 ). Among all products derived from glucose, gluconic acid and its salts are important industrial chemicals [9]. In 2007, its global annual production amounted to 100,000 tons per year. It is widely used in pharmaceutical, food and textiles industries. Gluconic acid displays also an important application in dairy and metallurgic industries based on its chelating properties with calcium, iron, copper, aluminum and other heavy metals. Currently, gluconic acid is manufactured by glucose microbial fermentation processes [7,8]. Gluconic acid and its derivatives can also be obtained by oxidation of aqueous glucose solutions in the presence of supported metal catalysts. Pd and Pt are the most common metals used for glucose oxidation [9–13]. These are often combined with promoters such as Bi, Sn and Te [14–19] which act as co-catalysts to improve the selectivity, activity and durability of Pd and Pt catalysts. Promoters are known to prevent overoxidation of the noble metal, arising from strong adsorption of oxygen on the metal surface. Recently a special interest has been focused on gold due to its high selectivity and high activity in carbohydrates oxidation [20–22]. However, usual deactivation phenomena, such as sintering and leaching, have restricted its industrial use [8]. Though it is known that biomass conversions are structure-sensitive reactions [23–26], the number of studies dealing with this subject for glucose oxidation over Pd supported catalysts is very poor [11]. The present study is focused on the preparation of Pd nanoparticles supported on carbon black catalysts by two different reduction methods, namely precipitation- reduction (PR) and urea-assisted sodium formate homogeneous deposition (HD) [27,28], in order to induce different particle sizes. The influence of catalyst synthetic methods and indirectly of Pd particle sizes on catalytic performance in the glucose oxidation reaction will be investigated. Moreover, to perform a significant particles size comparative study, the catalysts will be submitted to thermal treatment at 3 temperatures: 573K, 873K and 1173K to induce sintering and produce samples with gradually increased particle sizes. The carbonaceous material support has been selected for its non-porous structure which should help to avoid internal diffusional limitations implied in liquid phase reactions. The goal of this work is thus to determine the optimal Pd particles size in Pd/CB catalysts for the selective oxidation of glucose into gluconic acid. 2 Experimental section The carbon black support was received as 250G type from IMERYS GRAPHITE & CARBON (Fig. S1 in Supplementary data for textural characterization). It will be noted CB. It has been analyzed by ICP after acid digestion under microwave irradiation with a multi-element (10ppm) solution as reference. No trace of metallic element was found above 10ppm. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4, >98%), sodium tetrachloropalladate (II) (Na2PdCl4, 98%), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), ethylene glycol (EG, >99.5%), urea (99–100%) and sodium formate (FAM, 97%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. 2.1 Synthesis of Pd/CB catalysts Several Pd/CB catalysts were prepared by two synthetic strategies, namely precipitation-NaBH4 reduction (PR) and urea-assisted sodium formate homogeneous deposition (HD) process. In PR synthesis, a conventional precipitation-reduction method was used with NaBH4 as reducing agent: 4g of CB dispersed in 400mL of a Na2CO3 2.5wt.% aqueous solution were stirred 15min at room temperature. 285mg of Na2PdCl4 (corresponding to 2.5wt.% Pd in final activated catalyst) dissolved in 20mL of distilled water were added dropwise to the suspension within 1h. 5g of NaBH4 in 20mL of distilled water were then added. The suspension was stirred magnetically for 2h. Finally the catalyst was filtered out, washed with distilled water (1L) and dried overnight at 383K. For HD synthesis, 1.2g of urea were first dissolved in 300mL distilled water. 4g of CB were added and the mixture was stirred for 15min. To this solution, 285mg of Na2PdCl4 (2.5wt.% Pd) were added. After stirring for 1h, the mixture was heated to 393K for 1h and was then cooled down to room temperature. Next, 14g of sodium formate were added and the solution was stirred for 1h. Finally, the mixture was heated to 403K, kept for 1h at that temperature, cooled down, and stirred overnight at RT. The solid was filtered out, washed with distilled water (1L) and dried overnight at 383K 2.2 Characterization methods The solid catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Elemental analyses (ICP) and CO chemisorption. XPS analyses were carried out at room temperature with a SSI-X-probe (SSX 100/206) photoelectron spectrometer from Surface Science Instruments equipped with a monochromatized microfocus Al X-ray source. Samples were stuck onto small sample holders with double-face adhesive tape and then placed on an insulating ceramic carousel (Macor®, Switzerland). Charge effects were avoided by placing a nickel grid above the samples and using a flood gun set at 8eV. The binding energies were calculated with respect to the CC component of the C1s peak fixed at 284.8eV. Data treatment was performed using the CasaXPS program (Casa Software Ltd., UK). The peaks were decomposed into a sum of Gaussian/Lorentzian (85/15) after subtraction of a Shirley-type baseline. To evaluate the morphology of the samples, TEM images were obtained on a LEO 922 Omega Energy Filter Transmission Electron Microscope operating at 120kV. The samples were suspended in hexane under ultrasonic treatment. A drop of the supernatant was deposited on a holey carbon film supported on a copper grid (Holey Carbon Film 300 Mesh Cu), which was dried overnight under vacuum at room temperature, before introduction in the microscope. Thermograms were recorded on a TGA/SDTA 851e from Mettler Toledo. Samples (5–10mg) in alumina containers were heated at 10K/min under air flux. CO chemisorption measurements were carried out on an ASAP 2020 apparatus from Micromeritics. The samples (about 100mg) were degassed at 383K for 2h under dynamic vacuum. They were then submitted to a pretreatment under He at 373K for 30min. The catalysts were then reduced under hydrogen during 2h at 373K. The hydrogen was evacuated during 2h and once at room temperature again, CO was swept onto the samples. The Pd dispersion was calculated by considering a surface Pd:CO stoichiometry equal to 1. For XRD measurements, samples were introduced into 0.5mm thin-walled glass capillaries (Hilgenberg GmbH), mounted on a goniometer head and kept at 200mm from the detector. Diffractograms were then collected at room temperature using a MAR345 diffractometer (MarResearch GmbH), a Mo-Kα (0.71073Å) anode and a XENOCS focusing mirror. The obtained 2D diffractograms were azimuthally integrated using the Fit2D software and calibrated with a LaB6 standard (NIST 660b Standard). The elemental analyses (C, H, N, O, Pd) have been realized by MEDAC Ltd., UK by microgravimetry for C, H, N, O (direct measure) and by ICP after acid digestion for Pd. 2.3 Thermal treatment All the supported catalysts were submitted to a thermal treatment in a tubular oven STF 16/450 from CARBOLITE. The samples were placed into porcelain combustion boats and heated during 1h at the selected temperature (573K, 873K and 1173K, heating ramp and cooling ramp: 100K/h) under a N2 stream. Under these inert conditions, the carbon black support is not consumed. 2.4 Oxidative dehydrogenation of glucose: catalytic experiments The oxidation of glucose into gluconic acid was carried out in a 600mL thermostatized double-walled glass reactor. The pH of the glucose solution was measured continuously by a combined AgCl/Ag Beckman electrode. An automatic titration device Metrohm 842 Titrando was used to neutralize the acids formed over time with a 0.1M KOH solution to keep the pH at a constant value. Constant stirring was ensured by a mechanical stirrer (Heidolph RZR 2051 electronic). Oxygen was introduced in the solution under constant flow controlled by a flowmeter, using a bent glass tube. Experimentally, 500mL of milliQ water were added to the reactor containing 0.9g of glucose in order to obtain a concentration of 10mmol/L. When the temperature was set to 323K, the stirring rate was fixed at 1000rpm, the oxygen flow at 0.5mL/min and the pH was brought to 9 with the KOH solution. The test started when 0.100g of Pd/C catalyst- was added. After 4h of reaction with continuous pH control to keep it constant at pH=9, the catalyst was recovered by filtration and the filtrate, brought to 1L, was analyzed by HPLC. HPLC analysis was performed on a Waters system equipped with a refractive index 2414 detector and a UV 2998 Photodiode Array detector. To quantify gluconic acid, an Aminex BioRad HPX-87C column was used, with CaSO4 1.2mmol/L solution as eluent, a flow rate of 0.8cm3/min, a column temperature of 353K. Injected sample volume is 10μL. The gluconic acid yield was calculated using the equation: gluconicacidyield(%)=(mmolgluconicacid)/(mmolglucoseengaged)×100(%) Apart from gluconic acid obtained with >90% selectivity, the only by-product is fructose, produced by non-catalytic isomerization of glucose in very low amounts (<10%). No other carboxylic acid was detected, as in previous studies where a HPLC column specific for carboxylic acids and 13C NMR were used to confirm it [21,29]. 3 Results and discussion Several 2.5wt.% Pd/CB catalysts were synthesized by a precipitation-reduction method (PR) and a urea-assisted sodium formate (HD) homogeneous deposition process. We expect the HD method to give the smallest particle sizes because of slow pH rise promoted by urea, while the PR method uses faster reduction by NaBH4. The catalysts were heated at 573K, 873K and 1173K in order to produce catalysts with different particle sizes after a potential sintering process. The catalysts (heated or untreated) were characterized by XPS, TGA, ICP, CO chemisorption and TEM. The catalytic properties of all samples were evaluated in glucose oxidation. 3.1 XPS XPS characterization of all catalysts revealed that the palladium on the surface of the carbon black support was in metallic form for each synthesis method with binding energies between 335.4 and 335.9eV for Pd3d5/2 confirming the efficiency of the reduction processes (see Table 1 and Fig. S3 in Supplementary data for an illustrative example of spectra). The acquired XPS data also showed a decrease in Pd surface atomic% with increased temperature of the thermal treatment, due to thermally induced sintering leading to larger size Pd particles. As illustrated in Fig. S2 in Supplementary data, the XPS depth information being constant from one sample to another, it is logical that the detected Pd surface concentration gradually reduces with temperature for the same bulk content in Pd [30]. The XPS spectra disclose the presence of palladium, nitrogen and oxygen indicating that catalysts were not contaminated by chlorine from palladium precursor (Fig. S3 in Supplementary data). From XPS characterization, it was concluded that all catalysts could be used for catalytic glucose oxidation and that the thermal treatments appears to have modified the catalysts surface structure. The catalysts particle size distribution has also been studied in more details by TEM, as described below. 3.2 TGA TGA measurements were performed on the eight catalysts to determine the Pd mass percentage loaded on the support by the two synthetic methods. These TGA analyses were carried out under air to consume the CB support: hence the residue at high temperature is connected to the metal content. In order to achieve this, three catalysts with respectively 12wt.%, 6.5wt.% and 2.5wt.% of palladium were first prepared by HD process and analyzed by TGA in air. The TGA results were compared with ICP and calculated values of Pd loading. As shown in Fig. 2 , pure carbon black is completely consumed at 923K under air. On the contrary, when Pd is deposited on the CB support (b, c and d TGA curves) the catalysts give a high temperature residue. By comparing the results obtained by TGA (mass% corresponding to non-consumed residue) with theoretical (from engaged amounts of reactants) and ICP palladium mass% (Table 2 ), we see that the remaining mass in TGA curves can be attributed in each case to the palladium mass percentage loaded on the support. Thus, TGA measurements in air can be used to provide with speed and accuracy the mass percentage loading of noble metal in carbon-supported catalysts [31]. It was also noted that the ICP results (Table 2) are systematically lower than the values either calculated or extracted from TGA analysis. Moreover, the ICP undervaluation remains at a constant value of ∼10%, pointing towards a systematic error. This underestimation could be assigned to a difficulty of dissolving all the palladium present on carbon black in acidic solution, but not to metal impurities in the starting carbon. On the other hand, it is conceivable that under high temperature an oxide layer has been formed on palladium residues during TGA measurement. This layer could give an incorrect estimation of the palladium mass percentage loading. Nevertheless, the XRD phase analysis of the Pd residues obtained after TGA measurement (Fig. 3 a) shows clearly that these residues consist mainly of metallic palladium in comparison with references (Fig. 3b) [32,33]. In addition, the thermal behavior of Pd/PdO upon heating has been studied and it was shown that Pd metal is obtained at such high temperatures [34].We also observed on TGA curves a shift to lower decomposition temperatures for higher Pd mass percentage. This result implies that the deposited palladium nanoparticles accelerate the thermal decomposition of carbon black support in air. Moreover, in order to determine the precision of the Pd mass percentage determination obtained by TGA measurements (Table 3 ), one Pd/CB catalyst prepared by the PR method has been analyzed seven times. The mean palladium mass percentage obtained is 2.63 with a standard deviation of 0.39 (Table S1 in Supplementary data). This value is close to the theoretical value of 2.50wt.% and confirms the reliability of TGA measurements. Finally, the eight catalysts have then been analyzed by TGA in air in a similar manner. The palladium mass percentages obtained are reported in Table 3. All catalysts are close to the expected loading (2.5wt.%). The slight variations observed could be attributed to the preparation conditions. These catalysts were prepared on a larger scale (4g of carbon black) than the samples presented in Table 2. TGA curves of each Pd/CB catalyst, grouped by synthesis method, are also reported in Fig. 4 . For each given synthetic method, TGA curves are shifted to higher decomposition temperature with increasing thermal treatment temperature. The structure of Pd nanoparticles influences the temperature of carbon black support decomposition. As shown by XPS analyses, when the temperature of thermal treatment increases, the Pd nanoparticles size goes up. Therefore, it seems that the smaller is the Pd particle size, the lower is the CB decomposition temperature. This effect is ascribed to a catalytic role of Pd nanoparticles (increasing with diminishing Pd particle sizes) in CB decomposition. These results will be complemented by a particles size distribution study by TEM. 3.3 TEM and dispersion TEM images of Pd/CB catalysts prepared by the PR and HD methods and treated at 573K, 873K and 1173K are shown in Fig. 5 . Pd particles size distributions were built on no less than one hundred particles. As expected, TEM images clearly show the formation of larger Pd nanoparticles with higher temperature post-treatment with an average size of 4.0nm, 7.0nm, 12.3nm, 14.6nm (PR method) and 2.3nm, 3.4nm, 19.2nm and 30.4nm (HD method) for, respectively, untreated catalysts and samples thermally treated at 573K, 873K and 1173K (Fig. 5). In addition, the distribution range of RT catalysts is much narrower than when treated at 573K, which is also narrower than at 873K and 1173K. Those results corroborate the results previously obtained by XPS and TGA measurements. Pd dispersion values of each catalyst were measured by CO chemisorption (Table S2 in Supplementary data). Obviously the dispersion decreases with increasing heat treatment. The catalysts prepared by the HD method are initially better dispersed than by using the PR method, as expected. Here, particle size calculated from CO chemisorption values gives an average value which is meaningless, given the non-Gaussian particle sizes distributions and the presence of some much larger particles (see TEM images). 3.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic performance of synthesized catalysts was evaluated in model biomass reaction: the oxidative dehydrogenation of glucose into gluconic acid (Fig. 6 ). The yield in gluconic acid (%) was determined over time (see Fig. S4 in Supplementary data). As the different curves present similar trends and do not cross each other, we compare the different catalysts after a given reaction time, here 4h of reaction. The comparison between Pd/CB catalysts was made on the basis of yield (%), normalized activity (mmol gluconic acid produced per mmol Pd *time, in h−1 units) and initial activity values (k0cat., mmols−1) (Table 4 ). TOF values were also calculated taking into account metallic dispersion values (Tables S2 and S3 in Supplementary data). The gluconic acid yield ranges between 0% and 50%, which reflects the strong influence of Pd particles size on catalytic activity [11]. The preparation method and support are the same in all cases and, with the support being non porous, internal accessibility issues can be discarded (Fig. S1 in Supplementary data). We have performed standard tests for external mass transfer limitations (Fig. S5 in Supplementary data), by changing stirring rates and amounts of catalysts. To be on the safe side, we have selected the data obtained with 100mg of catalyst, where increasing the stirring rate has no influence on catalytic activity, and dividing the mass of catalyst gives a half yield. For discarding internal mass transfer limitations, we have grinded a catalyst and tested it in the same conditions, which also gave same performance. To compare the influence of Pd particles size on catalytic activity, we refer to the TEM images in Fig. 5. It should be noted that particle sizes are not affected by the catalytic test conditions (50°C in water), as demonstrated by TEM imaging after testing (see Fig. S6 in Supplementary data). The best yield (50%) was obtained with the catalyst prepared by PR method at 573K. As it can be observed in Fig. 5, the Pd nanoparticles produced by this method have an average size of 7nm. Moreover, with this method, the Pd nanoparticles were homogeneously deposited on the carbon black support. It was expected that urea-assisted method would produce catalysts with smaller Pd particle sizes than the PR preparation method [27,28]. It has been demonstrated that the in situ hydrolysis of urea enables a homogeneous gradual deposition of very small metal nanoparticles on a given support. Indeed, the HD samples at RT have an average particles size of 2.3nm±0.6nm (Fig. 5e). However, after thermal treatment at 573K, we have noted the formation of isolated large Pd particles (>10nm) aggregates in HD catalysts (Fig. 5f) which results in a broadening size distribution and rise in average size to 3.4±4.7nm. Nevertheless, we notice from particle sizes distributions that more than 60% of Pd nanoparticles have a size smaller than 4nm, even after the thermal treatment. Moreover, the Pd metallic dispersion does not change drastically when comparing the two HD samples at RT and 573K (Table S2 in Supplementary data). This shows the weak influence of the large Pd particles on dispersion and therefore on the catalyst activity. The behavior is dominated by the smallest ones. The lowest yields are observed with catalysts treated at the highest temperature (1173K). This is also not surprising. As previously shown in Fig. 5d–h, most Pd particles have a size larger than 12nm when catalysts were treated at this high temperature. This strong loss of activity is explained by a very low catalytically-active metal surface. This is shown in Table S2 in Supplementary data (giving values of metallic surface (m2/g sample)), where these samples appear with metallic dispersion values below 1%. The normalized activity values calculated by using the total amount of Pd in the catalysts follow the same trends as the yields. By contrast, the TOF values calculated using Pd dispersion measured by CO chemisorption (Table S3 in Supplementary data) do not respect the same tendency. This is due to the fact that particle size increases dramatically and the metal dispersion reaches very small value at high temperature (when treated at 1173K). Hence, when dividing quite similar activities by these very small numbers, very high TOF values are obtained artificially. We do not believe that these badly dispersed catalysts are the most performant. When looking at the activity versus time (Fig. S4 in Supplementary data), all catalysts behave similarly over time (parallel curves), indicating that there are not drastically different mechanisms occurring on our different particle sized catalysts. Parallel curves for catalysts with different particle sizes have been also shown before by other authors for this reaction [10]. We also calculated an initial activity (k0cat. in Table 4) based on the slope of the conversion versus time curves. The trends are the same as observations based on normalized activity values, which is logical because all the curves are parallel (within a series of heat-treated samples prepared by the same method). All these comments indicate clearly that the optimal Pd particle size for glucose oxidation is around 7nm (Fig. 7 ) which is in good agreement with the results reported by Parmon et al. [10]. They claimed that Pd/C catalysts with the smallest noble metal particle sizes (3nm) deactivate more rapidly hence are less performant. This particle size effect was also observed with gold catalysts [25] which corroborates the structure sensitivity of sugars oxidation. Based on the work of Besson et al., it was also proven that small Pd nanoparticles were less resistant to strong Pd-O bond formation which deactivates the catalyst [8]. This phenomenon could explain the difference in normalized activity values observed between a urea-assisted process and a PR conventional synthetic method. It is generally admitted that glucose oxidation proceeds according to an oxidative dehydrogenation mechanism [35], where the first step is abstraction of H atoms by the metal surface. Hence it requires available surface sites for sugar adsorption, and overwhelming oxygen coverage is deleterious. It is known that the presence of electronegative atoms such as O decrease the strength of H-atoms adsorption. The effect of surface site blocking for hydrogen is attributed to both steric and long-range electronic effects. In consequence, the smallest particles, highly covered in O atoms, are less active. Conversely, the largest particles are not able to either bind strongly the sugar molecules, or more importantly to carry out the dehydrogenation H cleavage, which is believed to be the rate-determining step. A direct comparison of activity values with catalysts from the literature cannot be made easily since the reaction parameters vary from a study to another. However, the values obtained in this work falls within the range of activity values reported in the literature [10,11,13] (Table S4 in Supplementary data): when comparing the normalized activity (in h−1), we obtained 32, while other authors report 21 or ∼50 with Pd catalysts supported on active charcoal (using respectively 5 and 3.5wt.% Pd loading). Using Bi promotors, the performance is greatly enhanced [13,19]. Nevertheless, these undergo substantial leaching which is a considerable drawback for industrial use. It has also to be noted that a loss of activity over time was always observed for each catalyst (Fig. S4 in Supplementary data), which is very common for non-promoted catalysts in this reaction. The oxidation of palladium catalysts is usually recognized as a deactivation phenomenon in glucose oxidation [10]. Here, Pd(0) was still the main component of Pd3d XPS photopeaks after 24h of reaction. Nevertheless Table 5 clearly shows a progressive increase in O1s atomic percentage and, a contrario, a decrease in surface Pd3d and C1s atomic percentage after four hours and twenty-four hours of catalytic test, respectively. The O/Pd surface ratio is above a stoichiometric Pd1:O1 ratio expected for the PdO oxide, therefore the surface oxygen content might be attributed to: (i) Pd coverage by O adatoms, (ii) carbon support oxygen coverage or (iii) adsorbed sugars which are oxygen-rich molecules. The last hypothesis can be discarded because TGA analysis of a spent catalyst showed no mass loss corresponding to carbohydrates (Fig. S7 in Supplementary data). Furthermore, the reaction mixture was analyzed by Pd atomic absorption after catalytic test. No Pd in solution was observed after the catalytic reaction. It should also be noted that no variation of Pd mass percentage was observed by TGA. This clearly shows that the decrease in Pd3d surface atomic percentage observed by XPS (Table 5) has not been caused by palladium leaching. These observations suggest that the catalysts were deactivated by a gradual formation of oxygen layers on the Pd particles. In summary, we found that Pd/CB catalysts present an optimal activity when particle sizes distribution is centered at a value of 7nm. This is probably a compromise between accessibility for sugar and oxygen coverage. On the smallest particles, oxygen coverage increases drastically, because of the presence of more edges and corners. On the largest particles, active metal surface is greatly reduced, hence the number of adsorption sites for sugar molecules, where it could be transformed, is diminished. This has been schematically sketched in Fig. 8 . One could also argue that a minimal step size is necessary for sugar adsorption. These steps or flat Pd surfaces do not exist anymore in the smallest particles, due to their high degree of curvature. 4 Conclusion In this work, the influence of particle sizes on catalytic performance in the oxidative dehydrogenation of glucose has been clearly evidenced for carbon black supported Pd nanoparticle catalysts. The supported catalysts were prepared by different reduction methods and were submitted to thermal treatment at 573K, 873K and 1173K to cover a broad range of palladium particle sizes (from 1 to 50nm). All the catalysts were characterized by XPS, TEM, CO chemisorption and TGA measurements. According to XPS and TEM, each catalyst discloses the presence of metallic palladium with a proportional increase in particles size with thermal treatment. We have also validated an unusual methodology to quickly determine the palladium mass percentage in each catalyst using TGA. The Pd/CB catalysts exhibiting the best catalytic activity present a metal particles size of 7nm. Below this size, the TOF values decrease due to rapid deactivation by oxygen deposition on palladium particles. Above this size, the active metal surface is greatly reduced. Nevertheless, oxygen coverage occurs after a while for each catalyst regardless of the catalyst preparation method. We have demonstrated that the catalytic activity is extremely sensitive to particle sizes. As it is quite tricky to control supported particle sizes within 1nm values, this shows how many reactions involving similar substrates could still be improved by using tailored catalysts.
